ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ATOMIC WAR-HEADS AND ROCKET SITES IN SINGAPORE


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether the Government will ascertain from the United Kingdom Government if any atomic war-heads are stored in Singapore and whether there are any atomic rocket sites in Singapore, and the extent of the potential danger to the people through accident.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I have sought the information asked for by the Member for Anson from the U.K. Commissioner. He has written to say that this question relates to matters of defence which under the Constitution is the responsibility of the British Government, and that it is not the practice in the United Kingdom, in answer to such questions to confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons at particular places.

    A point worth noting is that under the Communist proposals for full internal self-government with the Internal Security Council abolished, defence and foreign affairs will continue to be in the hands of the British.

    However, after independence through merger, defence will be in the hands of an elected government of the new and larger Federation, and members of the Central Parliament will be able to ask questions on matters of defence with more authority.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Does the Prime Minister recognise that it is not a question of locality, but a question of our entire State? The issue whether these atomic war-heads are in this State affects the safety and the survival of our people. Surely, from that point

Column: 118

of view, we are entitled to have some information in order to make some preparation for possible accidents.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Anson is now embarking on a debate. The Prime Minister has indicated his responsibilities, and I do not know whether he wishes to add to that.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I can only say that there are illustrious examples in the United Kingdom in the Committee of One Hundred. If the Member for Anson feels sufficiently strong about this matter of war heads being stored, as he suspects, either in the Naval Base or Changi, or wherever else the launching pads may be, he is not without precedent in this matter. The Government has always been more than ready and willing to allow all methods of peaceful persuasion and demonstration.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I seem to have been misunderstood. I am inquiring from the Prime Minister whether he has considered the aspects of possible accidents which will affect the safety and the survival of the people and, from that point of view, seek information of a general character indicated.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): In my somewhat rudimentary knowledge of the law of nuclear physics, I am convinced that accidents arise not in the bomb accidentally being exploded in the storehouse, but more, I believe, in a war being launched accidentally through misjudgment of each other's determination to resist. In that eventuality, Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson's safety and mine are similarly imperilled and I can only say that if we do not sleep well o'nights, then we shall all be very sick men indeed. It is a very sick world, Mr Speaker, Sir, and I do not wish to inflict upon the people of Singapore the deep horrors of gradual extinction in a nuclear fallout or of total annihilation in a nuclear holocaust -

    Mr David Marshall: What are you doing?

Column: 119



    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have suggested to the Member for Anson the illustrious examples of great philosophers like Bertrand Russell and other equally eminent and philosophic gentlemen. All that is required is sufficient verve, vitality and persistence through methods of democratic persuasion to bring home the misfortunes of having to be involved with deterrent weapons of destruction.

CIVIL DEFENCE PROVISIONS
IN TIME OF WAR


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether the Government will consider the feasibility of Civil Defence provisions for the people in time of war.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, token provision exists in the current Estimates to resuscitate the Civil Defence Corps should the necessity ever arise. Civil Defence provisions however, are only envisaged for the conventional type of warfare in what is now popularly called localised wars.

    I am informed that the dropping of a nuclear bomb in the megaton range on any city would wipe out the whole population and devastate the whole area. Against such a catastrophe, civil defence measures, as is understood, would be quite unrealistic.

    However, it is reported that some enterprising contractors in California, U.S.A., have made good sales of "fall-out" shelters. The Government understands, however, that these contractors are not sponsored by the U.S. Government.

    Mr David Marshall: In the light of the knowledge the Prime Minister has of the potential calamity for this area, would he indicate whether Government would give its support for an anti-nuclear movement here?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I have always been a great supporter of all movements to ensure the preservation of mankind. But I would like to draw the attention of the Member for Anson to

Column: 120

the fact that the danger is not particularly concentrated in any particular spot in the world. I see no particular incidence of annihilation being increased as a result of our being in a somewhat obsolete military base meant for localised wars in this area of the world. I am told that from time to time the Russians send off notes to not so friendly nations of their retaliatory and complete annihilative powers, and several governments have been in receipt of them, governments such as Pakistan and Turkey, who allow American bases and launching pads to be installed in their territories. However, I note that in none of the Russian notes to the United Kingdom Government has the Russian leader, Mr Khrushchev, singled out Singapore for special attention. However, that is not to say that I am not aware of the real danger of either slow death through a nuclear fallout or complete destruction of the world in a blazing holocaust if somebody accidentally misjudges the other side's temper and presses the button at the wrong time.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, could we have a reply to my question? Recognising the potential calamity for this area, would the Prime Minister indicate whether the Government would give its support for an anti-nuclear movement in this State? It is a simple question.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): The first question was whether I, as Prime Minister, would support and I have indicated that I give support for all movements for the preservation and upliftment of mankind. Now, the question is whether the Government would give its support. Without having consulted my colleagues, Sir, I give the Member for Anson the full assurance that, as we are all human beings on this side of the House who would like to see the survival of the human race, including human beings on the opposite side of this House, we will support all movements which seek to preserve the human race, defective though it may be, from total annihilation. If the Member for Anson could only indicate the time and place at

Column: 121

which his equivalent to the Committee of One Hundred would take action, we would ensure that adequate publicity is given to him through television, radio and other means.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE SCHEME


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Labour (a) whether the joint discussions between the Government, the Unions and the employers, with the view to agreement on unemployment insurance as the first step to a more comprehensive social security scheme, have taken place, and what is the outcome thereof; and (b) whether he will make a further statement of Government's intentions with regard to the introduction of social security measures during this session.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my colleague, the Minister for Labour, to reply to this question. The reason is that the Government held a series of meetings in December 1960 and January 1961 with certain Trade Union leaders to discuss, among other things, the introduction of an unemployment insurance scheme in Singapore and I represented the Government on that occasion. In all, five meetings were held and an agreed report prepared for submission to the Cabinet. The Trade Union leaders concerned in this series of meetings were Messrs. Lim Ching Siong, S. Woodhull, D. Puthucheary and S. T. Bani.

Column: 122



    This report has not been released earlier for publication at the request of the Trade Union leaders. I intend, however, to quote the section of the report dealing with unemployment insurance, as this would give a clear indication of the Government's attitude towards the subject of unemployment insurance. That section of the report reads as follows:

    `Unemployment insurance

    The Government side pressed the case for unemployment insurance on the basis of a 1½ per cent contribution by employer and employee. With an unemployment rate of 8 per cent, this would ensure unemployment benefits of about 40 per cent of wages earned during work. If the rate of unemployment is less, the rate of benefits could be increased. The Government proposed that the unemployment scheme be introduced and be restricted, in the first instance, to those industries demarcated for stability. A tripartite committee consisting of representatives of the Government, the T.U.C. and Employers should manage the Unemployment Insurance Fund and have powers to vary the rates of benefits in accordance with the financial state of the Fund. The Government's contribution would be to pay for all benefits during the first sear of the Fund's operation to allow the Fund to accumulate sufficient money from which it could earn interest to pay for administrative expenses. A detailed administrative scheme had been prepared by the Central Provident Fund and there are no administrative policy or other barriers to the immediate implementation of the Unemployment Insurance Scheme.

    The T.U.C. members supported the unemployment insurance in principle, hut requested that the matter be further considered by the T.U.C.

    In the course of discussion, the Government side stressed that redundancy schemes, severance pay and even unemployment insurance are no more than palliatives to a disease. These measures are intended to reduce the sharp edge of suffering caused by unemployment of workers. Further, where the worker finds it difficult to get another job, retrenchment often sparks off determined opposition from the workers, leading to strikes. The proposals considered and recommended would reduce the distress caused by unemployment. But it is not the basic solution: in fact, in themselves, they will do nothing to reduce unemployment.

    The only solution lies in creating conditions whereby the economy could expand at a sufficiently fast rate so that there will be more jobs than men available. When this position is reached, retrenchment and redundancy do not present any problem to the worker. Further, under such conditions, the way would he open for the worker to

Column: 123

obtain regular increases of pay through the collective bargaining power of the unions. It was recognised that the maintenance of stability in the industrial sector would he one of the factors conducive to industrial growth and economic expansion, and for this reason, both the Government and the T.U.C, representatives in the Sub-Committee are agreed that everything that could contribute to stability should be pursued, and that any measures that are inimical to it should be refrained from.'

That is part of the report.

    Now, Sir, although these trade unionists stated that they supported the unemployment insurance scheme in principle, they had taken no step whatsoever to obtain support from the workers for the principle of a contributory unemployment insurance scheme. In fact, in the course of discussions on the subject, they made it quite clear that they did not want such a scheme to be introduced.

    Hon. Members will note that these leaders had given an undertaking that they would refrain from any action which is inimical to stability and do everything to promote stability which is necessary in industrial expansion.

    Another section of the report puts the matter even more clearly when it says:

    'It will be the responsibility of the T.U.C, to ensure that industrial peace is maintained for the period of the agreement.'

It is now evident to everyone that these trade union leaders had not the slightest intention of honouring their pledge to the Government. Far from ensuring industrial peace, recent events -

    Mr David Marshall: On a point of order. The questions are simple and they are not being answered. Instead we are having polemics in respect of political opponents. Could the Minister be requested to confine himself to the question?

    Mr Speaker: The rule governing all questions is that an answer must be within the scope of the question asked. If it goes beyond the scope of the question asked, then, of course, the Minister is always entitled to make a ministerial statement. Whether he makes it now, or after questions is a matter of convenience, I leave it entirely to him.

    Mr Speaker: I do not think what the Minister has said has any strict relation to the motion, mentioned, which is:

    `That this House views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest and calls on the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure industrial peace...'.

I think the Minister is recounting what happened at a meeting of trade unionists and indicating how they had - as alleged by him - not kept their undertaking given to Government. But as the feeling of the Assembly is such, I think I ought to apply the Standing Orders very strictly and ask the Minister either to keep strictly to an answer to the question, or bide his time and wait until after questions to continue his statement.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am keeping strictly to the question. Questions of this kind have been coming in regularly from the Member for Anson and I wish to dispose of this issue once and for all. What I am saying will lead to the conclusion explaining just why and how negotiations with the trade union leaders for the implementation of social insurance came to nothing. Sir,I have to go into this matter in some detail to justify the conclusion that the Government has been completely reasonable all the time, but meeting with bad faith from the other side. This is strictly relevant to the question.

    Now, Sir, if I may be permitted to continue. The trade union leaders say they support unemployment insurance in principle but in practice they oppose it. Exactly in the same way, they say they support merger in principle but in

Column: 125

practice oppose it. Similarly, they support Malaysia in principle but oppose it in practice. Hon. Members are only too familiar with this kind of double-talk on the part of the Communists and their stooges in the Barisan Sosialis.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: P.A.P. side.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I must now rule the Minister completely out of order because answers to questions must be strictly statements which do not invite debate, and the Minister is obviously making a statement which does invite debate. So if he proceeds in that strain, I must stop him if he considers that that is the answer to the question. I have indicated that if he wishes to pursue that line of statement, then he must wait and make a ministerial statement at the end.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, if you had only borne with me for just two more seconds, you would have seen the relevance. As I was saying, in these circumstances, it is quite futile to have further discussions with those union leaders for the implementation of unemployment insurance, let alone a more expensive social security scheme.

    I may mention that I have had informal discussions with representatives of the employers' association in Singapore and they have agreed to support the contributory unemployment insurance scheme should the Government introduce such a measure. It is only certain trade union leaders who oppose this scheme. Why do they oppose it? The reason to me is quite simple. They do not want stability and progress in Singapore. They oppose unemployment insurance because this will reduce tension on the industrial front, and with a reduction of tension and discontent it will be difficult for them to foment trouble. If further evidence of their evil intentions is needed, my colleague, Mr Devan Nair, will only be too pleased to provide them. He told me of the advice which Mr Lim Ching Siong had given -

OVERSEA-CHINESE BANK
(Terms of settlement of strike)


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Labour whether he will indicate the broad terms of settlement of the strike of the employees of the Oversea-Chinese Bank in January this year.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the strike arose as a result of an allegation by the Singapore Bank Employees that the management had admitted to subverting its members by offering and making payments to some clerical employees of the Bank in accordance with the Bank's own interpretation of the recent award of the Industrial Arbitration Court, although the Bank knew that the Union had challenged the correctness of the Bank's interpretation and had declined to accept such payments pending a conclusive interpretation of the award by the Industrial Arbitration Court.

    Negotiations for the settlement of the strike did not take place in the Ministry of Labour or in the presence of Ministry officials. A Press report indicated that there had been an expression of regret by the management of the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation for the

Column: 127

payments made to some union members against the Union's stand. My Ministry also understand that the Union successfully contended that, as the strike was a justified one, the management of the Bank should compensate the members for their loss of pay during the strike and that the Managing Director of the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation, Mr Tan Chin Tuan, make a confidential payment of, a sizable sum of money to the Union for distribution to its employees in settlement of the Union's claim.

BATTLE FOR MERGER
(Total number published, cost of publication, and sale)


    8. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Culture to state the total number of Battle for Merger pamphlets published, the cost thereof, and the amount recouped by way of sales.

    Mr S. Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, two editions of the book were published - the hard cover edition selling for a dollar and containing appendices not included in the soft cover edition which is distributed free.

    The hard cover edition was initially printed in English, and the first impression of 5,000 copies were sold. The second reprint of another 5,000 copies were issued early this month. The cost of production of the 10,000 copies is $6,623. Some 7,500 copies have been sold as from 23rd February, and the amount recovered after commission to book-sellers is $6,062. 7,500 copies of the hard cover edition in Chinese were released for sale on 6th March. The cost of this edition is $5,125. We have no returns as to the number of copies sold since they were only put on sale less than a fortnight ago. There is also a print order of 2,000 copies in Malay, costing $1,615, which will be on sale shortly.

    As regards the soft cover edition, there was a first print of 100,000 copies in all the four languages at a cost of $29,159. All these have now been distributed in Singapore. However, in view of the demand for this edition not only in Singapore but also from the Federation and Borneo territories, a second reprint is now under production.

    Mr Rajaratnam: The photographs listed by the Member for Anson have been incorporated in the book for the same reasons as the other photographs in the book which the Member has not listed in his enquiries. The photographs either illustrate or amplify the text of the book. For example, on page 10 there is a photograph of the Member for Anson at the Baling Talks. He has quite rightly not questioned the propriety of its inclusion. Like the other photographs, it helps to illustrate or augment the main theme of the book, that is, the struggle between the non-Communist socialists on the one hand and the Communists and pro-Communists on the other to win the. hearts and minds of the people in Malaya. The Member for Anson will agree that all the photographs have been aptly chosen, including the one of himself.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE SCHEME
(Statement by the Minister for Finance)


3.08 p.m.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to the questions asked by the Member for Anson, I spent some time in explaining the background of our relations with the pro-Communist trade union leaders. Although we had discussions with them - we spent a lot of time working out the details of this unemployment insurance scheme - I harboured the doubt at that time, a doubt which subsequently turned out to be completely justified, that these persons were not honest nor sincere in their dealings with us.

    I went on to say that the main consideration of Communist leaders in a trade union movement is to maintain a hold on the union leadership. From this point of view, they will stop at nothing to achieve their objective. They have tried to hot up the situation, create an atmosphere of tension and uncertainty, because it is under such conditions approaching a revolutionary situation that a combat Marxist-Leninist Party can deploy its cadres to the most effective

Column: 133
